Question_1.Context: The paper discusses the development of a novel 18F-labeled analogue of the STING agonist acridone for imaging STING expression.
Question_1.Question: What is the main target of the novel 18F-labeled analogue [18F]F-CRI1?
Question_1.Source: STING is a transmembrane protein which plays important roles in cancer, cytotoxic therapies, and various infections. Several immunotherapy approaches designed to initiate anti-tumor immune response were shown to activate the cGAS-STING pathway and the therapeutic effects of the treatments are correlated with the STING expression within the tumor microenvironment (Corrales and Gajewski 2015).

Question_2.Context: The paper explores the production of the radioisotopes 43Sc and 44gSc using cyclotron irradiation of enriched calcium oxide targets.
Question_2.Question: What is the molar activity of 43/44gSc produced through proton and deuteron bombardment of isotopically enriched CaO targets?
Question_2.Source: The molar activity of 43/44gSc produced through a 30–60 min, 13.6 MeV proton energy and 5 μA current irradiation of either [43Ca]CaO or [44Ca]CaO targets was 48 ± 11 GBq/μmol (1.3 ± 0.3 Ci/μmol) (n = 3) at the end of chemistry.

Question_3.Context: The paper discusses the synthesis and evaluation of the 18F-labeled analogue of the STING agonist acridone, [18F]F-CRI1.
Question_3.Question: What is the potential application of [18F]F-CRI1 as mentioned in the paper?
Question_3.Source: High tumor-con- trast images and binding specificity suggest that [18F]F-CRI1 has potential for imaging STING.

Question_4.Context: The paper presents a study on the economic evaluation of in-house produced [177Lu]Lu-PSMA-I&T compared to radium-223 therapy.
Question_4.Question: What is the estimated cost-effectiveness of the in-house preparation of [177Lu]Lu-PSMA-I&T per QALY?
Question_4.Source: Therefore, the estimated cost-effectiveness of the in-house preparation of [177Lu]Lu-PSMA-I&T is €47.456/0.42 = €112.990 per QALY.

Question_5.Context: The paper discusses the development of a novel 18F-labeled analogue of the STING agonist acridone for imaging STING expression.
Question_5.Question: What is the main advantage of [18F]F-CRI1 as mentioned in the paper?
Question_5.B: High accumulation in the gastrointestinal tract
Question_5.Source: Small animal PET studies in CT26 tumor-bearing mice revealed gradual accumulation of [18F]F-CRI1 in the tumor reaching a peak at 1 h post-injection.

Question_6.Context: The paper discusses the sustained growth of new radioisotopes and radiopharmaceuticals, with a focus on 99mTc in diagnostic nuclear medicine.
Question_6.Question: What was demonstrated by the shutdowns of 99Mo-production reactors during the first decade of the 2000s?
Question_6.A: The reliability of the global medical isotope supply system
Question_6.B: The efficiency of 99mTc production in cyclotrons
Question_6.C: The cost-effectiveness of maintaining aging reactors
Question_6.D: The fragility and unpredictability of the global medical isotope supply system
Question_6.Source: During the first decade of the 2000s, shutdowns of 99Mo-production reactors demonstrated the fragility and unpredictability of the global medical isotope supply system.

Question_7.Context: The paper discusses the search for alternative sources of 99mTc due to interruptions in 99Mo-supply and aging reactors.
Question_7.Question: What has accelerated the search for alternative sources of 99mTc?
Question_7.B: Exorbitant costs of maintaining aging reactors
Question_7.D: The development of new cyclotron technologies
Question_7.Source: The global interruptions of 99Mo-supply, aging reactors, and the exorbitant costs of their maintenance have accelerated the search for alternative sources of 99mTc.

Question_8.Context: The paper discusses the feasibility of co-producing 99mTc in parallel with 18F using a hybridized system.
Question_8.Question: What is the proposed new strategy for the simultaneous production of 18F and 99mTc?
Question_8.B: Bombarding targets with protons in cyclotrons
Question_8.D: Utilizing a low energy biomedical cyclotron
Question_8.Source: A proposed new strategy allows for the simultaneous production of 18F and 99mTc in a low energy biomedical cyclotron available at many national facilities.

Question_9.Context: The paper discusses the use of terbium-161 for targeted radionuclide therapy in clinics.
Question_9.Question: What is the main advantage of terbium-161 over other isotopes?
Question_9.Source: The pace of this transition has surprised all as 161 Tb is the first Auger emitter (although a combination with betas) that is now becoming widely discussed.

Question_10.Context: The paper discusses the revolution of theranostics in nuclear medicine applications.
Question_10.Question: What is the most widely used theranostic matched pair of radionuclides mentioned in the paper?
Question_10.Source: The most widely used theranostic matched pair of radionuclides is by far 68Ga/177Lu.
